Cancer Prediction

Empowering individuals with early cancer prediction, paving the path towards proactive health management and improved outcomes.

How It Works

The determining factors of breast cancer play a crucial role in shaping the functionality of the model. These factors carry significant medical importance, serving as foundational elements utilized by the model for analyzing and predicting the likelihood of cancer occurrence.

Clump Thickness

Thickness of cell clusters. Higher values may indicate a higher likelihood of cancer.

Uniformity of Cell Size

Measure of how similar the sizes of cells are. Greater variation may suggest abnormal cell growth.

Uniformity of Cell Shape

Similar to cell size, this measures the consistency of cell shapes. Irregular shapes might indicate cancerous changes in the cells.

Marginal Adhesion

Measures how well cells stick together. Increased adhesion could be linked to cancer, as cancer cells often lose the ability to adhere properly.

Single Epithelial Cell Size

Evaluates the size of individual epithelial cells. Larger sizes may be associated with cancer, as cancer cells tend to be larger and more irregular.

Bare Nuclei

Indicates the presence of cell nuclei without surrounding cytoplasm. Higher values might suggest abnormal nuclear morphology, often observed in cancer cells.

Bland Chromatin

Assesses the appearance of chromatin in the cell nucleus. Increased bland chromatin may be indicative of abnormal cell division, a characteristic of cancer.

Mitosis

Measures the frequency of cell division. Higher mitotic activity may indicate uncontrolled cell growth, a hallmark of cancer.
